_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Solvay USA Inc.

Charleston, South Carolina Facility

Risk Management Plan Program

Executive Summary



INTRODUCTION



The Charleston Plant is part of the Novecare  Enterprise within Solvay.  The Charleston Plant has a long history of chemical manufacturing stretching back over a century.  The facility uses state of the art technologies to monitor and safely control the chemical processes at the Charleston Plant.  The Executive Summary is intended to provide a condensed description of the following sections 1 - 7, to provide a better understanding of the chemicals handled at the Charleston Plant, and the accident prevention and emergency response programs, which are designed to prevent accidental releases, and to respond appropriately if an accidental release does occur. 



1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies

2. A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation

3. A summary of results from our assessment of the potential off site consequences from accidental chemical releases

4. An overview of our accidental release prevention program

5. A five-year accident history of accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule

6. An overview of our emergency response program

7.  An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment



1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY

RESPONSE POLICIES



At Solvay's Charleston, SC plant site, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.   The operations of the Charleston Plant are subject to strict internal company policy requirements regarding the management of health, safety and environmental issues.  The Charleston Plant is also subject to a number of local, state and federal regulatory r

equirements to which Solvay adheres.    We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management programs we have developed and implemented.



2. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The Charleston, SC Plant produces inorganic and specialty organic chemicals using a variety of chemical raw materials and processing operations.  These chemical products are produced in several separate production units using batch and continuous manufacturing processes.  The Charleston Plant does not produce chemicals purchased directly by consumers, but produces chemical intermediates and products sold to and used by other industrial manufacturing organizations.   Chemicals produced at the Charleston Plant include products used as flame retardants in synthetic materials like fabrics, plastics and foams; products used in the industrial water treatment business; agricultural products; products used in the pharmaceutical manufacturing business; and a range of other products.



3. OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS



EPA's RMP regulation requires that Solvay provide information about worst-case accidental release scenarios and alternative accidental release scenarios at our facility for the chemicals listed in Section 2.  In compliance with the regulation, Solvay has assessed the impact of worst case scenarios for each of the listed chemicals in Section 2. The submitted document includes a worst case scenario for the toxic chemical with the greatest potential impact in terms of distance, and a worst case scenario for the one flammable chemical on the list.  Solvay has also conducted a hazards assessment to identify potentially more likely or alternate accidental release scenarios for each of the listed chemicals, and in compliance with the RMP regulati

on, has included in the document submitted to EPA a single alternate accidental release scenario for each of the listed chemicals. Consistent with revisions to the RMP rule by EPA, no information on the consequences of accidental release of the regulated chemicals is provided in the Executive Summary. 



4.  GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Charleston Plant has a number of processes covered under the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management regulation, 29 CFR 1910.119. The Charleston Plant also has a well-established process safety management program which meets, and in some cases exceeds, the requirements of this OSHA regulation. Many of these same processes are also covered under the requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program rule. In complying with the above regulations, the Charleston Plant takes a systematic, integrated approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals and planning for emergencies.   Solvay plants, including the Charleston Plant, are required to implement the requirements of Solvay's Process Hazards Management Program (PHMP), an internal process safety management system.  PHMP is designed to incorporate all regulatory requirements of process safety and risk management, but also includes additional best practices in the management of process safety.  Since the submission in 1999, the Charleston Plant has made program improvements.  The most important has been the adoption of a Layers of Protection Analysis methodology to better analyze process hazards, and assess if adequate layers of protection are in place to provide acceptable risk reduction.  Many of the PHA revalidations have included the application of this method to reassess the major process hazards.  These programs are described in a Process Safety and Risk Management Plan for the Charleston Plant. The key elements of the accident prevention program are listed below:  



o Process safety informa

tion

o Process hazard analysis

o Operating procedures

o Training

o Mechanical integrity

o Management of change

o Pre-startup safety review

o Compliance audits

o Incident investigation

o Employee participation

o Hotwork permit

o Contractors



Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems establish the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.



5.  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the five-year period ending October 24, 2014, there have not been any accidents meeting the reporting criteria established by the RMP rule.    



6.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Charleston Plant has a comprehensive Emergency Response Plan that covers all types of emergencies, including naturally occurring emergencies such a hurricanes. This plan is subject to a number of regulatory requirements but primarily those under the US Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA). Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Our plan includes procedures in communications, evacuation, emergency organization, emergency response, decontamination and operation and maintenance of emergency equipment.



Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the community emergency response plan and conduct joint training with the local fire department and Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).



7. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Solvay implemented a number of improvements in process safety since submission in 1999.  These have included additional leak detection equipment in three separate operating areas, additional fire water monitors, and upgrading of the process control software in two process units to make the software more secure.  The largest improvements have been the installation of ethylene oxide and propylene o

xide storage tank to improve the on-site safety of handling ethylene oxide, and the installation of a generator providing emergency power to two units to maintain safety systems following a power failure. Solvay plans to make a number of improvements to fire protection systems.
